revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/2.82.37.41|2.82.37.41]] ([[User talk:2.82.37.41|talk]]) to last version by KolbertBot
revision.text:
'''''Postminimalism''''' is an art term coined (as '''''post-minimalism''''') by [[Robert Pincus-Witten]] in 1971<ref name="Dictionary">Chilvers, Ian and Glaves-Smith, John, ''A Dictionary of Modern and Contemporary Art'', second edition (Oxford and New York: Oxford University Press, 2009), p. 569. {{ISBN|0199239665}}.</ref> used in various artistic fields for work which is influenced by, or attempts to develop and go beyond, the aesthetic of [[minimalism]]. The expression is used specifically in relation to music and the visual arts, but can refer to any field using minimalism as a critical reference point. In music, ''postminimalism'' refers to music following [[minimal music]].
==Visual art== {{See also|List of postminimalist artists}} In visual art, postminimalist art uses minimalism either as an aesthetic or conceptual reference point. Postminimalism is more an artistic tendency than a particular movement. Postminimalist artworks are usually everyday objects, use simple materials, and sometimes take on a "pure", [[Formalism (art)|formalist]] aesthetic. However, since postminimalism includes such a diverse and disparate group of artists, it is impossible to enumerate all the continuities and similarities between them.
The work of [[Eva Hesse]] is also postminimalist: it uses "grids" and "seriality", themes often found in minimalism, but is also usually hand-made, introducing a human element into her art, in contrast to the machine or custom-made works of minimalism. [[Richard Serra]] is a prominent post-minimalist.<ref>Smith, Roberta (April 14, 2011). "[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/15/arts/design/richard-serras-drawings-at-metropolitan-museum-of-art.html?pagewanted=all Richard Serra's Drawings at Metropolitan Museum of Art]", ''NYTimes.com''. Accessed 8 June 2012.</ref>
==Music==<!-- This section is linked from [[Mamoru Fujieda]]. See [[WP:MOS#Section management]] --><!--[[Postminimalism (music)]] and [[Postminimal music]] redirect directly here.--> {{See also|List of postminimalist composers}} In its general musical usage, ''postminimalism'' refers to works influenced by [[minimal music]], and it is generally categorized within the meta-genre [[art music]]. Writer [[Kyle Gann]]<ref name="Gann2001">Kyle Gann. 2001. "[https://web.archive.org/web/20110604040811/http://www.newmusicbox.org/article.nmbx?id=1536 Minimal Music, Maximal Impact: Minimalism's Immediate Legacy: Postminimalism]". ''New Music Box: The Web Magazine from the American Music Center'' (November 1) (Accessed 4 February 2012).</ref> has employed the term more strictly to denote the style that flourished in the 1980s and 1990s and characterized by: #a steady [[pulse (music)|pulse]], usually continuing throughout a work or movement; #a [[diatonic scale|diatonic]] pitch language, [[tonality|tonal]] in effect but avoiding traditional [[diatonic function|functional tonality]]; #general evenness of [[dynamics (music)|dynamics]], without strong climaxes or nuanced emotionalism; and #unlike [[minimalism]], an avoidance of obvious or linear formal design.
Minimalist procedures such as [[additive rhythm and divisive rhythm|additive]] and subtractive [[process music|process]] are common in postminimalism, though usually in disguised form, and the style has also shown a capacity for absorbing influences from world and popular music ([[Balinese gamelan]], [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]], Jewish [[cantillation]], and so on).
For a musical style derived from minimalism, see [[Totalism (music)]].
==See also== {{col-begin}} {{col-3}} * [[Holy minimalism]] * [[Lyrical Abstraction]] * [[Neo-expressionism]] * [[New York School (art)|New York School]] * [[Fluxus]] * [[Conceptual art]] * [[Appropriation (art)]] * [[Post-Minimal Ambient]] {{col-3}} * [[Institutional Critique]] * [[Postmodern art]] * [[Art software]] * [[Computer art]] * [[Internet art]] * [[Electronic art]] * [[Systems art]] * [[Cyberarts]] {{col-3}} * [[New Media]] * [[New Media Art]] * [[Computer generated music]] * [[Generative art]] * [[Monochrome painting]] * [[Neo-minimalism]] * [[Timbral listening]] * [[Post-conceptual]] {{col-end}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.newmusicbox.org/page.nmbx?id=31tp00 Minimal Music, Maximal Impact] by [[Kyle Gann]] © 2001 NewMusicBox * [http://www.kylegann.com/postminimaldisc.html A Discography of Postminimal, Totalist, and Rare Minimalist Music] by Kyle Gann * [http://www.minusspace.com/ MINUS SPACE reductive art]

{{dablink|For the risk-reward tradeoff, see [[risk-return spectrum]]}} {{Infobox film | name = Risk/Reward | image = Poster of the movie Risk Reward.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | director = [[Elizabeth Holder]]
[[Xan Parker]] | producer = Elizabeth Holder
Xan Parker | writer = | narrator = | starring = Louise Jones
Carol Warner Wilke
Kimberley Euston
Umber Ahmad | music = [[Mj Mynarski]] | cinematography = [[Cynthia Wade]] | editing = [[Rachel Kittner]] | studio = | distributor = [[Organic Pictures]]
[[Roland Park Pictures]] | released = 2003 | runtime = 88 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Risk/Reward''''' is a 2003 [[documentary film]] about women on [[Wall Street]]. It follows the lives of four Wall Street women - a research analyst, a currency trader, an NYSE floor broker and a [[rookie]] [[investment banker]]. It was directed by [[Elizabeth Holder]] and [[Xan Parker]] and produced by [[Roland Park Pictures]]. The documentary features Louise Jones, Carol Warner Wilke, Kimberley Euston, and Umber Ahmad; and includes appearances by Roslyn Dickerson, [[Muriel Siebert]], Ann Kaplan, Janet Tiebout Hanson, Sheila Wellington and Maria Bartiromo. ''Risk/Reward'' was released theatrically in [[New York City]] and [[Chicago]] and was televised on [[Oxygen Media]]. ==Accolades== The film was an official selection of: [[Tribeca Film Festival]], Hot Docs International Documentary Film Festival, [[Full Frame Documentary Film Festival]], Maryland Film Festival, Starz Denver Film Festival, [[Philadelphia Film Festival]], [[Rhode Island Film Festival]], Central Standard Film Festival, Rocky Mountain Women's Film Festival, Northampton Film Festival.[http://www.rolandparkpictures.com/riskreward.html/link_1 Roland Park Pictures | Productions | Risk/Reward] ==Awards== *[[Sarasota Film Festival]] ("Best of the Fest") *Baltimore Magazine August 2003 ("Best Documentary") ==References== == External links == * [http://www.rolandparkpictures.com/riskreward.html/link_1 Risk/Reward Official Website] *{{IMDb title|0358079}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Risk Reward}} [[Category:2003 films]] [[Category:American women in business]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:Documentary films about businesspeople]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Documentary films about women]] [[Category:Wall Street films]] {{bio-documentary-film-stub}}

[[File:RosinaCazali.jpg|thumb|Photo of Rosina Cazali at the Absurdo simposium in Quetzaltenango, Guatemala in 2013.]] '''Rosina Cazali''' (born 1960) is a Guatemalan art critic and independent curator. She serves as an advisory committee member for CIFO (The Cisneros Fontanals Art Foundation).<ref>{{cite web|title=CIFO Advisory Committee Members|url=http://www.cifo.org/index.php/component/k2/item/559-advisory-committee|website=CIFO|publisher=CIFO|accessdate=9 March 2015}}</ref> Cazali currently works as a columnist for ''[[El Periódico (Guatemala)|El Periódico]]'', a Guatemalan newspaper. She recently co-curated the 2014 Guatemalan Biennial, XIX Bienal de Arte Paiz,<ref>{{cite news|title=19th Bienal de Arte Paiz "Transvisible"|url=http://www.artnexus.com/PressReleases_View.aspx?DocumentID=27677|accessdate=10 March 2015|publisher=Art Nexus|date=January 5, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=TRANSVISIBLE, LA BIENAL DE ARTE PAIZ 2014|url=http://revistagimnasia.com/noticiasblog/2014/8/20/transvisible-la-bienal-de-arte-paiz-2014|website=Revistagimnasia.com|publisher=Revista Gimnasia|accessdate=10 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702144347/http://revistagimnasia.com/noticiasblog/2014/8/20/transvisible-la-bienal-de-arte-paiz-2014|archivedate=2 July 2015|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Transvisible in 19th Paiz Biennale|url=http://www.arteporexcelencias.com/en/news/2014-06-14/transvisible-19th-paiz-biennale.html|website=Arte Por Excelencias|publisher=Arte por Excelencias|accessdate=10 March 2015}}</ref> along with [[Cecilia Fajardo-Hill]], Anabella Acevedo and Pablo José Ramírez.
== Life and career == She studied arts at Universidad de San Carlos de Guatemala and attended the first Cultural Studies lectures organized by FLACSO (Latin American Faculty of Social Sciences, 2011)
She works as an independent curator since 2000 and founded several art projects such as La Curandería and Los Tres Tiempos, art essays editorial (2014)
From 2003 to 2006 Cazali was director of the Spanish Cultural Center in Guatemala where she started projects like the photography festival Foto 30 and the editorial project Colección Pensamiento,a compilation of interviews with Guatemalan intellectuals on contemporary thought, supported by the Spanish Cultural Centre in Guatemala.
Among her notable projects are La Curandería, Colloquia, Octubreazul and Proyecto Laica. She was a member of the first curatorial team of the Bienal de Arte Paiz, which in 2014 has had 19 editions, but prior to 2008 was not a curated event.<ref>{{cite web|title=Contests & Awards: Rosina Cazali|url=http://www.artnexus.com/Notice_View.aspx?DocumentID=21811|website=ArtNexus|publisher=ArtNexus|accessdate=9 March 2015}}</ref>
Between 2003 and 2005 she curated several exhibitions on contemporary art in Guatemala and Central América. One of them was Outsiders, an important look over indigenous contemporary art in Guatemala.
In 2007 she was invited by Fundación TEOR/éTica of Costa Rica to participate in Estrecho Dudoso (Doubtful Strait), a large-scale visual arts event celebrated at several institutional venues and public spaces of San José, Costa Rica. For this event she curated a monographic exhibition of Margarita Azurdia, a fundamental Guatemalan artist from the 1960s.
She also participated as a guest curator for Guatemala in different international biennials and as an independent curator for several exhibitions in Guatemala and Latin America.
Some of these include Móvil, an exhibition and performance by Guatemalan artist Regina José Galindo at the Museo de Arte Contemporáneo (MUAC) and UNAM’s independence bi-centenary celebration project: The Ghost of Liberty, México 2010.
She curated Mirando al Sur, an itinerant show about migration in Central America and México exhibited in Miami, México, the Dominican Republic, Central America and the Pontevedra Biennale in Galicia, Spain, in 2010.
With Laura Terré she co-curated the exhibition Peso y Levedad, Photography in Contemporary Latin America, for the Instituto Cervantes de Madrid, within the activities of PHOTO España, 2011.
In the same year she curated with Emiliano Valdés the exhibition El proyecto inconcluso, a panoramic exhibition on contemporary painting in Central America.
She has participated in theoretical events such as: Temas Centrales, organized by Teorética in San José, Costa Rica in 2000 and 2012; Curatorial Practice and Criticism in Latin America, by Bard College’s Center for Curatorial Studies, New York, March 2011; IV Diálogos Iberoamericanos/POST Issues, Valencia, Spain 2001; No title, International Symposium on Latin American Art in Global Context, the University of Austin, Texas, March 2006; ARCO’s debate forums, Madrid, Spain 2006; Contemporary Art in Guatemala. A Comparative Lecture, New Mexico University, Alburquerque, September 2008; Contemporary Art in Guatemala, 3 type events at the seminar Tras Signos en Rotación, organized by the project Ojo Atómica and Anti-Museo, Spanish Cultural Center in México, 2009;La vida nuda, preliminary encounter at Kasell Documenta in México City and Cairo; Between the museum and practice: Reconsidering Latin American Art in the XXI Century, Museum of Latin American Art, MOLAA, Long Beach, California, in collaboration with the Getty Research Institute, Lima, Perú 2011; Foro Latinoamericano de Fotografía de São Paulo, Brasil, 2013; Daegu Photography Biennial and Symposium, Seul, Korea. 2014.
She participated as a photography reviewer for Photo-España’s portfolio review events in Madrid, São Paulo, Managua and Cartagena/Colombia.
In recognition to her trajectory, she was invited to participate in the project 9 Curators, organized by Gerardo Mosquera and the Spanish Cultural Centers in Argentina and Chile.
Rosina Cazali is an author of countless essays about contemporary art in Guatemala. In 2010 she published the essay A Brief History of Dissociation, about the work of the Guatemalan artist Luis González Palma. This essay was included in the Latin American Photorgraphers’ Library, part of the Photo Bolsillo collection of the editorial house La Fábrica, Spain.
She was invited as a speaker to discuss performance art and video art in Guatemala at the event Performing Localities, organized by the Royal College of Art, London, 2009.
She was part of the Orientation Trip 2010, which took place in Istambul, Lagos and Bamako and was realized by the Mondrian Foundation and the Prince Claus Foundation. In 2011 she was invited to teach a workshop entitled Inmonumental, a review and deconstruction of the symbols and discourses of the monuments as part of the contemporary art project Demolition/Construction, in Córdoba, Argentina. In March 2012 she was invited by ICI, Independent Curators International, to be part of the Curator’s Perspective, an itinerant public discussion series that features international curators who distill current happenings in contemporary art, and their views on recent developments in the art world; the New Museum of Art, New York. In 2010, she received the John Simon Guggehnheim Grant to conduct research on contemporary art in Guatemala. She works and resides in Guatemala City, Guatemala. In 2014 she received from Fundación ArsTeorética, San José Costa Rica, a grant for research on Grupo Imaginaria, a collective of artists from the 80’s in Guatemala.
Between December 2008 and March 2010, the ''Migraciones: Mirando al Sur'' exhibit traveled through Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Mexico, United States of America, and Costa Rica—showing at the Spanish Cultural Centers of each country. This group exhibit included 12 Central American contemporary artists, including Adán Vallencillo, Lucía Madriz, and Patricia Belli.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Migraciones: Mirando al Sur|journal=Art Nexus|date=March–May 2010|issue=9 no76|pages=124–125}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=MIGRACIONES: MIRANDO AL SUR Arte Centro Cultural Español Miami|url=http://es.artealdia.com/International/Contenidos/Resenas/Migraciones_Mirando_al_Sur|website=Arte Al Dia|publisher=Arte Al Dia|accessdate=9 March 2015}}</ref>
In 2014 she coordinated El día que nos hicimos contemporáneos, a theoretical symposium with emphasis in Central American thought and discussions centered in a reflection about contemporary art in the isthmus and its development. The symposium also was the frame for the exhibition with the same name, in celebrarion of the XX Anniversary of the Museo de Arte y Diseño Contemporáneo, in San José, Costa Rica.
== Awards and recognition == In 2010 Cazali was granted a fellowship for Visual Arts Research in the field of Humanities<ref name=Guggenheim>{{cite web |url=http://www.gf.org/fellows/16919-rossina-cazali |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-08-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141219160744/http://www.gf.org/fellows/16919-rossina-cazali |archivedate=2014-12-19 |df= }}</ref> in order to develop research on Guatemalan art production between 2000 and 2010.
In 2014 Cazali was honored with the [[Prince Claus Awards]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Rosina Cazali gana premio Príncipe Claus 2014 en Holanda|url=http://www.soy502.com/articulo/rosina-cazali-gana-premio-principe-claus-2014-holanda|accessdate=10 March 2015|agency=Soy 502|publisher=Soy 502|date=December 12, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ROSINA CAZALI, UNA DE LAS GALARDONADAS CON EL PREMIO PRINCE CLAUS 2014|url=http://revistagimnasia.com/noticiasblog/2014/9/5/rosina-cazali-una-de-las-galardonadas-con-el-premio-prince-claus-2014|website=revistaGimnasia.org|publisher=Ciudad de la Imaginación|accessdate=10 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150311153509/http://revistagimnasia.com/noticiasblog/2014/9/5/rosina-cazali-una-de-las-galardonadas-con-el-premio-prince-claus-2014|archivedate=11 March 2015|df=}}</ref>
== Exhibitions == * ''Móvil'', an exhibition and performance by Regina José Galindo, Museo de Arte Contemporáneo (2011)<ref>http://www.proceso.com.mx/?p=261598</ref> * ''Migraciones: Mirando al Sur Arte'', organized by the Spanish Cultural Center Network of AECID and curated by Cazali (2009)<ref>{{cite book|title=Migraciones: Mirando al Sur|date=2009|publisher=Proyecto de la Red de Centros Culturales de AECID|location=Mexico|isbn=978-607-95229-9-5|url=http://www.cervantesvirtual.com/obra/migraciones-mirando-al-sur-catalogo-de-la-exposicion-proyecto-de-la-red-de-centros-culturales-de-la-aecid/|accessdate=9 March 2015}}</ref> * ''Imaginaria, Disidente'', [[Centro Cultural de España en Guatemala]] (2015)<ref>{{cite news|last1=Velásquez|first1=Jefferson|title=Arte de un grupo disidente|url=http://www.dca.gob.gt/index.php/entertainment-2/item/25497-arte-de-un-grupo-disidente|accessdate=10 March 2015|agency=Diario de Centro America|issue=Web|date=February 5, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Imaginaria, disidente|url=http://hipermedula.org/2015/01/imaginaria-disidente/|website=Hipermedula|publisher=Hipermedula|accessdate=10 March 2015}}</ref>
== Bibliography == * Cazali, Rosina. ''Pasos a Desnivel: mapa urbano de la cultura contemporanea en Guatemala''. HIVOS & laCuranderia. Guatemala City, 2003. Print. * Cazali, Rosina. ''Luis González Palma: PHoto Bolsillo.'' La Fábrica, 2011. Print. * Cazali, Rosina. ''Estados de Excepción'', 2014. Print. * Cazali, Rosina, and Fernando Castro Florez. Regina José Galindo. Milan: Silvana Editoriale, 2011. Print.

{{DEFAULTSORT:Cazali, Rosina}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:Art curators]] [[Category:Guatemalan art critics]] [[Category:Women curators]] [[Category:Laureates of the Prince Claus Award]] [[Category:Art critics]] [[Category:Guatemalan women writers]]

The '''San Ildefonso Self-Taught Group,''' was an art movement from 1900–1935<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|url = http://digitalcommons.unl.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1103&context=historyfacpub|title = Shaping a New Way: White Women and the Movement to Promote Pueblo Indian Arts and Crafts,1900-1935|last = Jacobs|first = Margaret D.|date = 1998|journal = DigitalCommons@University of Nebraska - Lincoln|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 2015-01-12}}</ref> and a group of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] artists primarily from the [[San Ildefonso Pueblo, New Mexico|San Ildefonso Pueblo]] in New Mexico. The group consisted of [[Tonita Peña]], [[Julian Martinez]], [[Awa Tsireh|Alfonso Roybal]], Abel Sanchez, [[Crecencio Martinez]], [[Encarnación Peña]], and others.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.stanford.edu/news/2012/february/pueblo-painting-exhibit-022212.html|title=Highlights from Stanford's Native American paintings collection are showcased in ''Memory and Markets: Pueblo Painting in the Early 20th Century''|last=|first=|date=2012-02-22|website=Stanford University|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2016-01-12|quote="Well-known artists such as Tonita Peña and Alfonso Roybal, both from the San Ildefonso Pueblo, are represented in Memory and Markets. Peña was the only woman in the San Ildefonso Self-Taught Group, which included such noted artists as Roybal, Julian Martinez, Abel Sanchez, Crecencio Martinez, and Encarnación Peña."}}</ref> This group was the first known Native American group in the [[Southwestern United States|American Southwest]] to practice easel painting.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Journal of Intercultural Studies, Volumes 24-26|last = |first = |publisher = Intercultural Research Institute, Kansai University of Foreign Studies|year = 1997|isbn = |location = |pages = 58}}</ref>
== History == [[Edgar Lee Hewett]], a professor of archaeology and the director of the Laboratory of Anthropology in Santa Fe, was working closely with locals from the San Ildefonso pueblo on excavations. He said that he "discovered" their ability to draw and paint in watercolor.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = The Modern West: American Landscapes, 1890-1950|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Z3DNuRni76kC|publisher = Yale University Press|date = 2006-01-01|isbn = 0300114486|first = Emily Ballew|last = Neff}}</ref> Hewett encouraged the production of art work from Native American artists and helped gain them financial support of white patrons.<ref name=":0" />
The artwork is often composed of the subject matter, Native American ways of life. The work uses flat and using bright colors. It was celebrated as an American way of contemporary abstraction.<ref name=":0" /> Artists who tried to veer way from that style were discouraged by their patrons.<ref name=":0" />
=== Critics === During the early 20th century, numerous white Americans became involved in an effort to promote Native American arts within white social circles.<ref name=":1" /> Critiques of the San Ildefonso Self-Taught Group have been made by those who study "traditional" Native American art, versus art of Native Americans supported (and perhaps shaped by) white patronage.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Tonita Peña (Quah Ah), Pueblo Painter: Asserting Identity through Continuity and Change on JSTOR|jstor = 1184742}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:American art movements]] [[Category:Native American art]] [[Category:Native American artists]] [[Category:People from San Ildefonso Pueblo, New Mexico]]

{{More footnotes|date=February 2008}} The '''Scandinavian Institute of Comparative Vandalism''' ({{lang-da|Skandinavisk institut for sammenlignende vandalisme}}) is a [[non-profit organization|non-profit]] cultural [[institute]] based in [[Denmark]].
It was founded in 1961 by the [[Denmark|Danish]] artist [[Asger Jorn]], [[Peter Glob]] and [[Werner Jacobsen]] from the [[National Museum of Denmark]] and [[Holger Arbman]] of the [[University of Lund]], [[Sweden]].<ref name = Henriksen>{{cite journal | author= Niels Henriksen | title= Asger Jorn and the Photographic Essay on Scandinavian Vandalism | journal= Inferno | year= 2003 | volume= VIII | url= http://eprints.st-andrews.ac.uk/archive/00000369/01/11_-_Article_5_-_%5B8%5D.pdf }}</ref> Jorn had recently left the [[Situationist International]], although he continued to support them financially. The stated purpose of the institute was to throw new light upon the Scandinavian culture in the age of migrations and Vikings. For several years, Jorn toured around Scandinavia and Europe with photographer Gérard Franceschi, former photographer for French writer and onetime culture minister [[André Malraux]] on his ''Musée imaginaire'' project, photographing ancient, [[Romanesque art|Romanesque]], Scandinavian, and [[Gothic art|Gothic]] figurative and decorative motifs in order to trace the connections between Scandinavian and European motifs. [[Jacqueline de Jong]] was also involved in several of these excursions.
In 1965, the [[Silkeborg]] municipal government provided a building to store over 20,000 photographs taken by Jorn, [[Gerard Franceschi]] and [[Ulrik Ross]].<ref name = Henriksen/> Jorn was working with the publisher Skandinavisk Forlag in Odense to publish a series of books based on his research and documentation called ''10,000 Years of Nordic Folk Art'' (''10 000 års nordisk folkekunst''). Jorn gave up the project that year, however, when the press Skandinavisk Forlag refused to proceed unless the project was run by a committee of scholars, with Jorn having only one vote. He wanted total control of the subject of each volume.<ref>Anneli Fuchs, "Roots and Perspective: Asger Jorn and Tradition in Art," in ''Asger Jorn'' (Ishøj: [[Arken Museum of Modern Art]], 2002), 107</ref> The Institute remained as a sort of imaginary museum, now housed in the [[Silkeborg Kunstmuseum]], home of Jorn's art collection and archives. Jorn continued to publish articles and books on the subject of Nordic art as a tradition independent of what he called the "Classical-Latin" tradition.
A publication series of theoretical texts (without illustration) in the name of the institute (''Meddelelse fra Skandinavisk institut for sammenlignende vandalisme'') encompasses four books, all by Jorn * ''Naturens Orden'' (1962) * ''Værdi og økonomi'' (1962) * ''Held og Hasard'' (1963) * ''Alfa og Omega'' (1980 posthumous)
==References== <references/>
* ''Comparative Vandalism: Asger Jorn and the artistic attitude to life'' by [[Peter Shield]], Borgen/Ashgate (1998) * ''The Natural Order and Other Texts'' by Asger Jorn (Translated by Peter Shield), Ashgate (2002)

{{Redirects|Side stick||Rimshot}} [[File:Airbus A380 cockpit.jpg|thumb|[[Airbus A380]] flight deck showing side-sticks]] [[File:F16 ohjaamo.jpg|thumb|F-16 cockpit showing side-stick]] A '''side-stick''' or '''sidestick controller''' is an [[aircraft]] control column (or [[joystick]]) that is located on the side console of the [[Aviator|pilot]], usually on the righthand side, or outboard on a two-seat [[Cockpit (aviation)|flightdeck]]. Typically this is found in aircraft that are equipped with [[fly-by-wire]] control systems.<ref name="Crane">Crane, Dale: ''Dictionary of Aeronautical Terms, third edition'', page 463. Aviation Supplies & Academics, 1997. {{ISBN|1-56027-287-2}}</ref>
The throttle controls are typically located to the left of the pilot (or centrally on a two-seat flightdeck). Only one hand may thus be used for the stick, and both-hands operation is neither possible nor required.
The side-stick is used in many modern military [[fighter aircraft]], such as the [[F-16 Fighting Falcon]], [[Mitsubishi F-2]], [[Dassault Rafale]], and [[F-22 Raptor]], and also on civil aircraft, such as the [[Sukhoi Superjet 100]], [[Airbus A320]] and later [[Airbus]] aircraft,<ref name=fbw_sidestick>{{cite web |url = http://www.airbus.com/innovation/proven-concepts/in-design/fly-by-wire/ |title = Fly-by-wire - A CIVIL AVIATION FIRST |work = Airbus / Innovation / Proven concepts / In design / Fly-by-wire |publisher = [[Airbus]] |accessdate = 6 July 2012 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120708070059/http://www.airbus.com/innovation/proven-concepts/in-design/fly-by-wire/ |archivedate = 8 July 2012 |df = }}</ref> including the largest passenger jet in service, the [[Airbus A380]].
This arrangement contrasts with the more conventional design where the stick is located in the centre of the cockpit between the pilot's legs, called a "[[centre stick]]".
In the centre stick design, both the pilot's and co-pilot's controls are mechanically connected together so each pilot has a sense of the control inputs of the other. In typical Airbus side-stick implementations, the sticks are independent. The plane's computer either aggregates multiple inputs or a pilot can press a "priority button" to lock out inputs from the other side-stick.<ref name=getline>{{Citation | last = Getline | first = Meryl | author-link = Meryl Getline | title = Ask the captain | journal = USA Today | date = 2005-11-21 | origyear = | url = https://www.usatoday.com/travel/columnist/getline/2005-11-21-ask-the-captain_x.htm | jstor = }}</ref> However, if both side sticks are moved in different directions (regardless of which pilot has priority), then both inputs are cancelled out. Examples of this occurrence include the 2009 crash of [[Air France Flight 447]] (an [[Airbus A330]] flying from [[Rio de Janeiro]] to [[Paris]]), and the 2015 crash of [[Indonesia AirAsia Flight 8501]] (an [[Airbus A320]] flying from [[Surabaya]] to [[Singapore]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2009/06/12/is-flight-447-fly-by-wire-aircraft-technology-safe/|title=Is Flight 447's 'Fly-by-Wire' Aircraft Technology Safe?|date=2009-06-12|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=2013-05-29}}</ref><ref name="Ross">{{Citation|last=Ross|first=Nick|title=Air France Flight 447: 'Damn it, we're going to crash'|date=2012-04-28|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/9231855/Air-France-Flight-447-Damn-it-were-going-to-crash.html|quote=It seems surprising that Airbus has conceived a system preventing one pilot from easily assessing the actions of the colleague beside him. And yet that is how their latest generations of aircraft are designed. The reason is that, for the vast majority of the time, side sticks are superb.|type=article|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]}}</ref>

{{Infobox Theatre |name = Stenborg Theatre |image = |caption = |address = |city = [[Stockholm]] |country = [[Sweden]] |designation = |latitude = |longitude = |architect = |owner = Carl Stenborg |capacity = |type = |opened = 1784 |yearsactive = 1784-1799 |rebuilt = |closed = 1799 |othernames = Munkbroteatern, Svenska Komiska Teatern, Komiska Teatern |production = |currentuse = |website = }} The '''Stenborg theatre''', also called '''Svenska Komiska Teatern''', '''Komiska Teatern''' and '''Munkbroteatern''', was a historical Swedish 18th century theatre, active between 1784 and 1799 in [[Gamla stan]] in [[Stockholm]]. It was the second theatre of Stockholm during the Gustavian age. In 1784-87, before the inauguration of the theatre of Ristell in [[Bollhuset]], it was the only dramatic theatre of the native language in Stockholm.
== History ==
===Background=== The Stenborg theatre was a continuation of the famous [[Stenborg Troupe]]; when the first Swedish national theatre at [[Bollhuset]] was closed in 1753–54, half of the troupe performed in various localities in the city under the leadership of [[Petter Stenborg]]. When the national stage was re-established by king [[Gustav III of Sweden]] in 1773, it did not include the old Stenborg troupe. In 1780, the troupe had finally acquired a proper house to perform in; Eriksbergsteatern, (The Eriksberg Theatre), and in 1781, the leadership was taken over by Petter Stenborg son, Carl Stenborg. In 1780–84, the Eriksberg Theatre was the only permanent theatre on the native language in Stockholm.
The Erikberg Theatre was uncomfortably outside of town, and the Stenborg troupe under Carl Stenborg searched for a new building. They made a partnership with the rich brewer [[Christina Nyman]], who wanted to establish a theatre in Gamla stan and had obtained a permission to do so. The theatre was housed in a large building erected in Gamla Stan in 1782; the first floor housed four taverns and several apartments, while the second floor was reserved for the Stenborg troupe. From 1784, it was formally named ''Svenska komiska Teatern'' (Swedish Comical Theatre) or ''Svenska Teatern'' (Swedish Theatre) and from 1788 ''Komiska Teatern'' (Comedy Theatre). It was also known as ''Munkbroteatern'' (The Munkbro Theatre), after its location. The common name for it was always the Stenborg Theatre.
===Activity=== The theatre was luxuriously decorated and was in 1784 called the biggest theatre in the country. The theatrically interested king was present at its premier and gave away gifts to its performers. However, it did not have the same status as the [[Royal Swedish Opera]] and [[Royal Dramatic Theatre]] and was considered much less formal: it was a place for less formal and solemn performances, a place for satirical comedy and such, and foreigners sometimes compared it to a boulevard-theatre of the kind that was popular in [[Paris]]. I also performed less formal opera and musicals. ''[[The Barber of Seville]]'' had its Swedish premiere here in 1785, as well as ''[[The Marriage of Figaro]]'' in 1792. Also foreign guest-artists and [[circus]]-performances were given here; in the autumn of 1793, the English circus-company of Peter and James Price performed acrobatics and tight-rope-dancing here, were the four-year-old Louise Price danced on a rope. The theater's status as a less serious theatre did not stop actors from the Royal Swedish Opera and the Royal Dramatic Theatre to appear there; even [[Elisabeth Olin]] had performed here, and it was in fact used by actors and singers to work in during their conflicts with the managements with their regular stages.
The director Carl Stenborg, who was a celebrated [[opera singer]] at the Royal Swedish Opera, resided in one of the apartments, where he and his wife, the singer Betty Olin, hosted gatherings and parties for the cultural elite of the city. The theatre often took their staff from the choir at the Royal Opera, but it also took in its own students. An advertisement in 1786 read as follows: :"If some common parents, who own children of a beautiful appearance and a good voice, would like to have them educated, for their own benefit, in a talent which may be beneficial to their future, they may have an education and a reward answering to their ability, when they enlist at the royal secretary Stenborg at the New Swedish theatre house at Munkbron".<ref>Johan Flodmark : Stenborgska skådebanorna (The Stenborg Stages) {{sv icon}}</ref>
===Closure=== In 1798, the new monopoly of the royal theaters was proclaimed in the city of Stockholm, and the Stenborg theatre was closed the year after (the monopoly was in effect until 1842). The building itself was torn down in 1899.

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Italic title}} {{Infobox television | show_name = The Atheist Experience | image = Atheist_Experience_Banner.jpg | caption = | genre = Talk show | starring = * [[Matt Dillahunty]] * Russell Glasser * Don Baker * [[Jeff Dee]] * Tracie Harris * John Iacoletti * Jen Peeples * [[Martin Wagner (artist)|Martin Wagner]] * Phil Session | theme_music_composer = [[Shelley_Segal|Shelly Segal]] | opentheme = "Saved"<ref>{{cite web|title=The Atheist Experience Technical FAQ|url=http://www.atheist-experience.com/faq/|website=www.atheist-experience.com|publisher=Atheist Community of Austin|accessdate=March 22, 2015}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = <!-- Or num_series. Increment when new seasons/series begin or production starts. --> | num_episodes = 1000 (as of June 24th, 2018) | list_episodes = | producer = * Shelley Roberts * Frank Paschal | editor = | location = [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], Texas | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = 90 minutes | distributor = | channel = <!-- or network --> | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = <!-- The nation in which the series first aired, if different from country parameter. --> | first_aired = {{start date|1997|10|19}} | last_aired = present | related = <!-- To be used only for remakes, spin-offs, and adaptations. --> | website = http://www.atheist-experience.com }}
'''''The Atheist Experience''''' is a weekly [[webcast]] based in [[Austin, Texas]]. It first aired on October 19, 1997. Rotating regulars [[Matt Dillahunty]],<ref>[http://star.txstate.edu/node/4838 New group helps students understand atheism, [[University Star]], Retrieved 2012-06-02] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306041021/http://star.txstate.edu/node/4838 |date=March 6, 2012 }}</ref><ref>[http://wtamu.edu/news/wtamu-lecture-to-debate-christian-and-atheist-doctrines.aspx WTAMU Lecture to Debate Christian and Atheist Doctrines, [[West Texas A&M University]], Retrieved 2012-06-02]</ref> [[Jeff Dee]], [[Martin Wagner (artist)|Martin Wagner]], Russell Glasser, Don Baker, Tracie Harris, Jen Peeples, John Iacoletti, and Phil Session host and co-host the program. Frequent topics include religious [[dogma]], [[religion and morality|morality]], [[religion and ethics|ethics]] and application of the [[scientific method]].<ref>[http://libguides.ben.edu/content.php?pid=109030&sid=820383 Understanding Peer Reviewed, [[Benedictine University]], Retrieved 2012-06-02] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140505182014/http://libguides.ben.edu/content.php?pid=109030&sid=820383 |date=May 5, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.holykoolaid.com/atheist-podcasts/|title=Atheist Skeptic and Freethought Podcasts|work=Holy Koolaid|access-date=2018-01-03|language=en-US}}</ref> The co-host often opens with a theme or current event, then takes live calls. Although debates about all theist- and atheist-related views are welcome, because of the large number of [[Christian]]s in the United States, the emphasis is mostly on [[Christianity]].<ref name=GallupChristmas09>[[The Gallup Organization|Gallup]], [http://www.gallup.com/poll/124793/this-christmas-78-americans-identify-christian.aspx "This Christmas, 78% of Americans Identify as Christian"], December 24, 2009. Accessed February 8, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://b27.cc.trincoll.edu/weblogs/AmericanReligionSurvey-ARIS/reports/p1a_belong.html American Religious Identification Survey 2008] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110518163841/http://b27.cc.trincoll.edu/weblogs/AmericanReligionSurvey-ARIS/reports/p1a_belong.html |date=May 18, 2011 }}</ref><ref name="Pew">[[Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life]]. [http://religions.pewforum.org/pdf/report-religious-landscape-study-full.pdf ''U.S. Religious Landscape Survey: Religious Affiliation: Diverse and Dynamic'']. February 2008, pp. 5, 12. Accessed February 8, 2011.</ref>
''The Atheist Experience'' is broadcast by the Atheist Community of Austin (ACA), an educational non-profit organization based in [[Austin, Texas]]. The ACA has as a central goal the promotion of positive atheism and the [[separation of church and state]].<ref name="tae_official_site">{{cite web |title= The Atheist Community of Austin |url= http://www.atheist-community.org/ |accessdate= 2012-04-03 }}</ref>
A [[YouTube]] channel which became the official channel in August 2012 has over 220,000 subscribers and over 52 million video views as of August 2018.<ref>http://www.statsheep.com/TheAtheistExperience/statsheep</ref><ref>http://socialblade.com/youtube/user/theatheistexperience </ref><ref> {{cite web |url= https://www.youtube.com/user/TheAtheistExperience |publisher= YouTube |title= The Atheist Experience }} </ref>
==Personalities== [[Matt Dillahunty]] was raised a [[Christian fundamentalism|fundamentalist Baptist]]<ref>[http://be.umbc.edu/videos/show/236232 The Source of Human Morality Debate, [[University of Maryland, Baltimore County]], Retrieved 2012-06-02] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111115115845/http://be.umbc.edu/videos/show/236232 |date=November 15, 2011 }}</ref> and was a Christian for more than 20 years. He served in the Navy for 8 years and spent several years in the hi-tech game industry. After this, he set out to re-affirm his faith with the intent of attending seminary and pursuing a life in the ministry,<ref name=flynn>{{cite news |title=Preaching his own gospel of atheism |author=Eileen E. Flynn |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=AASB&p_theme=aasb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=117F829CB4CBAFA0&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |newspaper=[[Austin American-Statesman]] |date=March 18, 2007 |accessdate=February 3, 2012}}</ref> but through a process of study, no longer believed his previous theistic beliefs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Saving believers: Former Christian finds calling to preach the good news of atheism |publisher=Richard Dawkins Foundation for Reason and Science |url=http://richarddawkins.net/articles/765 |date=March 21, 2007}}</ref> He co-founded Iron Chariots, a counter-[[apologetics]] [[wiki]].<ref name="tae_profile_dillahunty">{{cite web |url=http://www.atheist-experience.com/people/matt_dillahunty/ |publisher=The Atheist Experience |title=Profile of Matt Dillahunty}}</ref> Dillahunty served as the president of the Atheist Community of Austin.<ref name="aca_board">{{cite web |url=http://www.atheist-community.org/activism/board.php |publisher=Atheist Community of Austin |title=Board of Directors}}</ref>
{{vanchor|Russell Glasser}} is a software engineer in Austin, Texas. He received an MSc in computer engineering at the University of Texas in 2007.<ref name="personal_profile">[http://www.apollowebworks.com/russell/ Russell Glasser, personal profile]</ref> Glasser is the producer of the internet radio show ''The Non Prophets''.<ref>"PBS MediaShift – Public-Access TV Fights for Relevance in the YouTube Age", Mike Rosen-Molina, December 17, 2008 [https://www.pbs.org/mediashift/2008/12/public-access-tv-fights-for-relevance-in-the-youtube-age352.html]</ref><ref name="tae_profile_glasser">{{cite web |url=http://www.atheist-experience.com/people/russell_glasser/ |publisher=The Atheist Experience |title=Profile of Russell Glasser}}</ref> He has a son, Ben.<ref name="personal_profile" />
{{vanchor|Jen Peeples}} is an aerospace engineer. She served in the [[U.S. Army]] for 26 years, retiring as a lieutenant colonel, was a military test pilot and left the military as an aviation officer.<ref>"She later earned a commission and spent 9 years on active duty, first as a Field Artillery officer, then as an Aviation officer." {{cite web |url=http://blip.tv/the-atheist-experience-tv-show/jen-peeples-convenient-lies-about-don-t-ask-don-t-tell-4891291 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-04-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120101035428/http://blip.tv/the-atheist-experience-tv-show/jen-peeples-convenient-lies-about-don-t-ask-don-t-tell-4891291 |archivedate=January 1, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Peeples is a self-described [[There are no atheists in foxholes|"foxhole atheist"]].<ref name="tae_profile_peeples">{{cite web |url=http://www.atheist-experience.com/people/jen_peeples/ |publisher=The Atheist Experience |title=Profile of Jen Peeples}}</ref> She is openly gay.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MpcIrBbEoSk&spfreload=1 |author= Atheist Experience |date= September 18, 2011 |title= Atheist Experience #727: Defunding Planned Parenthood |publisher= [[YouTube]] |accessdate= July 15, 2016}}</ref>
[[Jeff Dee]] (May 15, 1961) is an artist and [[game designer]]. He is a recognized figure in the [[role-playing game]] community and game industry.<ref>Olivo, Benjamin (March 9, 2007). "Leatherface to rev up ChimaeraCon action", ''[[San Antonio Express-News]]'', p. H16.</ref> His illustrative work shows [[comic book]] art form and influence. He is the co-creator of ''[[Villains and Vigilantes]]'',<ref>{{cite news |first=Harley |last=Jebens |title=Game central |newspaper=[[Austin American-Statesman]] |page=38 |date=September 21, 1995}}</ref> illustrator of the ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' manual ''[[Deities & Demigods]]'', artist for ''Master of Orion'',<ref>{{IMDb title|1037029}}</ref> art director for ''[[Ultima VII]]'', and lead designer for ''[[The Sims: Castaway Stories]]''. He co-created ''The Non Prophets'', an internet radio show by the Atheist Community of Austin.<ref name="tae_profile_dee">{{cite web |url=http://www.atheist-experience.com/people/jeff_dee/ |publisher=The Atheist Experience |title=Profile of Jeff Dee}}</ref>
[[Martin Wagner (artist)|Martin Wagner]] (April 27, 1966, [[Henderson, Nevada]]) is an artist, cartoonist, and filmmaker. Wagner was a prominent figure in the short-lived comics self-publishing movement, along with Dave Sim (''Cerebus''), Jeff Smith (''Bone''), and Colleen Doran (''A Distant Soil'').<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1332625/bio "Biography for Martin Wagner"]</ref> He self-published the comic book ''[[Hepcats]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hepcats.comicgenesis.com/about.html |publisher=Comic Genesis |title=Hepcats by Martin Wagner}}</ref>
{{vanchor|Tracie Harris}} (Orlando, Florida) is a graphic artist, cartoonist, and publishing professional who does the ''Atheist Eve'' strip hosted on the Atheist Community of Austin web site. She received her [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in Liberal Studies from the University of Central Florida. Harris is a former [[Christian fundamentalism|Christian fundamentalist]].<ref name="tae_profile_harris">{{cite web |url=http://www.atheist-experience.com/people/tracie_harris/ |publisher=The Atheist Experience |title=Profile of Tracie Harris}}</ref><ref name="atheisteve">[http://www.freethunk.net/atheisteve/atheisteve.htm "Freethunk – Atheist Eve"]</ref> Harris and Dillahunty were featured on the Religion section of ''The Huffington Post'' "facing down an aggressive Christian caller with a shocking view of children who have been the victims of rape."<ref>{{Cite news |title='Atheist Experience' TV Host Shocked By Caller's Statement About Child Rape (VIDEO) |first=Meredith |last=Bennett-Smith |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/08/atheist-experience-child-rape_n_2434198.html |date=January 8, 2013}}</ref>
{{vanchor|Don Baker}} is a PhD computer scientist working in the field of computer-supported cooperative work.<ref name="atheisteve" /> He has taught at the University of Texas (Austin) as an adjunct for two years. Baker is a board member of the Atheist Community of Austin. He has a strong interest in the nascent field of memetics and has spent several years exploring the implications of Christianity as a meme complex, expressed in his writings at ''Christianity Meme''.<ref name="tae_profile_baker">{{cite web |url=http://www.atheist-experience.com/people/don_baker/ |publisher=The Atheist Experience |title=Profile of Don Baker}}</ref> Baker serves as the secretary of the Atheist Community of Austin.<ref name="aca_board"/>
{{vanchor|Phil Session}} became a co-host in season 20, having previously worked as part of the television crew.

Topic: "Greg Paul and Atheist Civil Rights." Russell and Don talk with sociologist/evolutionist Greg Paul about atheist civil rights and healthy societies.", YouTube [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CxUtPLVwgWQ]</ref> * [[Ray Comfort]], Evangelical Christian apologist (episode #702), live call-in<ref name="Episode Archive">[http://www.atheist-experience.com/archive/?full=1 "The Atheist Experience Show Archive"]</ref><ref>"Matt Dillahunty and Russell Glasser with guest Ray Comfort. Interview with Ray Comfort. Matt and Russell have a conversation "across the divide" with professional apologist Ray Comfort." [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zyzF8SMQOxU]</ref> * [[David Silverman (activist)|David Silverman]], president of American Atheists (episode #701, 2011-03-20), live call-in<ref name="Episode Archive" /><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yKQcgC9qg_8 "Atheist Experience #701 20 Mar 11", YouTube]</ref> * [[Aron Ra]],<ref>[http://www.darwindaybroward.com/speakers.html "AronRa (L. Aron Nelson) is a YouTube atheist and activist."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315124113/http://www.darwindaybroward.com/speakers.html |date=March 15, 2012 }}</ref> [[Video blogging|vlogger]]<ref>"AronRa – 1st appearance on the Atheist Experience, ep #648 [..] 2nd appearance on the Atheist Experience, ep #668 [..] 3rd appearance on the Atheist Experience, ep #703" [http://www.aronra.com/]</ref> and Texas state director of the American Atheists (episodes #648, #668, #703, #875), live guest appearances<ref name="Episode Archive" /><ref>The Atheist Experience TV Show #648: Interview with AronRa, Host: Matt Dillahunty, Guest: AronRa, YouTube Celebrity, 2010-03-14 {{cite web |url=http://blip.tv/the-atheist-experience-tv-show/atheist-experience-648-interview-with-aronra-3365348 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-04-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402001823/http://blip.tv/the-atheist-experience-tv-show/atheist-experience-648-interview-with-aronra-3365348 |archivedate=April 2, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * [[Kathleen Johnson (soldier)|Kathleen Johnson]], vice-president of American Atheists and founder of the [[Military Association of Atheists & Freethinkers]] (episode #647, 2010-03-07), guest appearance<ref name="Episode Archive" /> * [[Darrel Ray]], organizational psychologist (episode #645, 2010-02-21; #686, 2010-12-05), guest appearances<ref name="Episode Archive" /> * Kyle Miller, pastor (episode #639, 2010-01-10), guest appearance<ref name="Episode Archive" /> * [[Matt Slick]], Evangelical Christian apologist (episode #593 broadcast February 22, 2009), live call-in<ref name="Episode Archive" /> * [[Victor J. Stenger]], particle physicist (episode #499, 2007-05-06), guest appearance<ref name="Episode Archive" /><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7KJw9Uqymtc |title=Vic explains the scientific case against God's existence}}</ref><ref>"Oct, 29 Thu Austin TX, 6:30 pm, Threadgill's Old Number One (Longhorn room), 6416 North Lamar, Austin, TX. Atheist Community of Austin. http://www.atheist-community.org/. Don Rhoades. The Atheist Experience. Interview with Don Baker. On web." [http://www.colorado.edu/philosophy/vstenger/VWeb/Events.html]</ref> * Mark Loewe, theoretical physicist (episode #393, 2005-04-24), guest appearance<ref name="Episode Archive" />
==Affiliations== Since its launch on July 29, 2014, ''The Atheist Experience'' has been affiliated with [[AtheistTV]], the world's first atheism-dedicated television channel.<ref name="Salon AtheistTV">{{cite news|last1=D'Addario|first1=Daniel|title=I spent a day watching AtheistTV – and it was horrifying|url=http://www.salon.com/2014/08/09/i_spent_a_day_watching_atheisttv_and_it_was_horrifying/|accessdate=January 6, 2015|work=Salon|date=August 9, 2014}}</ref> Distributed through the [[Roku]] streaming television network, and available through online streaming through the [[American Atheists]] webpage, Atheist TV's playlists and programming include the latest ''The Atheist Experience'' episodes.
==Awards== * [[About.com]] Readers' Choice Awards 2012, Favorite Agnostic / Atheist Podcast of 2011<ref>{{cite news |first=Austin |last=Cline |publisher=[[About.com]] Guide |title=Readers' Choice Awards, 2012 |url=http://atheism.about.com/od/ReadersChoiceAwards/ss/Readers-Choice-Awards-2012_4.htm |date=2012}}</ref> * ''[[The Austin Chronicle]]'', Best of Austin 2012: Best Public Access TV Show<ref>{{cite news |newspaper=[[The Austin Chronicle]] |title=Best of Austin 2012: Best Public Access TV Show: The Atheist Experience |url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/best-of-austin/year:2012/poll:readers/category:media/the-atheist-experience-best-public-access-tv-show/ |date=November 9, 2012}}</ref> * ''[[The Austin Chronicle]]'', Best of Austin 2011: Best Public Access TV Show<ref>{{cite news |newspaper=[[The Austin Chronicle]] |title=Best of Austin 2011: Best Public Access TV Show: The Atheist Experience |url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/best-of-austin/year:2011/poll:readers/category:media/the-atheist-experience-best-public-access-tv-show/ |date=October 14, 2011}}</ref> * About.com Readers' Choice Awards 2011, Best Atheist Podcast, 2010<ref>{{cite news |first=Austin |last=Cline |publisher=[[About.com]] Guide |title=Readers' Choice Awards, 2011 |url=http://atheism.about.com/od/aboutthenews/ss/Readers-Choice-Awards-2011_8.htm |date=2011}}</ref> * ''[[The Austin Chronicle]]'', Best of Austin 2010: Best Public-Access TV Show: 'The Atheist Experience'<ref>{{cite news |newspaper=[[The Austin Chronicle]] |title=Best of Austin 2010: Best Public-Access TV Show: 'The Atheist Experience' |url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/best-of-austin/year:2010/poll:readers/category:media/the-atheist-experience-best-public-access-tv-show/ |date=September 3, 2010}}</ref>
==Documentary film== ''{{vanchor|Mission Control Texas}}'',<ref>{{IMDb title|4137928|Mission Control Texas (2015) }}</ref> a German documentary film about ''The Atheist Experience'', directed by Ralf Bücheler, premiered at the Max Ophüls Film Festival in [[Saarbrücken]] in January 2015,<ref>{{citation|title=Filmfestival Max-Ophüls-Preis " MISSION CONTROL TEXAS|publisher=Saarbrücken Interaktiv|year=2015|url=http://www.max-ophuels-preis.de/film_abc_detail/movie-54a96fc7cd147|accessdate=May 19, 2015}}</ref> and showed at DOK.fest in Munich in May 2015.<ref>{{citation|title=Festival program: Mission Control Texas|publisher=DOK.fest München|year=2015|url=http://www.dokfest-muenchen.de/filme_view_web.php?fid=7463}}</ref>

page.title: The Day I Became a Woman

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = The Day I Became a Woman | image = TheDayIBecameAWoman.jpg | image_size = | caption = Movie poster | director = [[Marzieh Meshkini]] | producer = [[Mohsen Makhmalbaf]] | writer = Mohsen Makhmalbaf
Marzieh Meshkini | narrator = | starring = | music = [[Ahmad Reza Darvish]] | cinematography = [[Mohamad Ahmadi]]
[[Ebrahim Ghafori]] | editing = [[Maysam Makhmalbaf]]
[[Shahrzad Pouya]] | distributor = Olive Films (U.S.) | released = September 1, 2000 | runtime = 78 mins. | country = [[Iran]] | language = [[Persian language|Persian]] | budget = $180,000 (estimated) | gross = $344,235 (USA sub-total) | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Day I Became a Woman''''' ({{lang-fa|italic=yes|Roozi ke zan shodam}}, روزی که زن شدم) is a [[2000 in film|2000]] award-winning Iranian [[drama film]] directed by [[Marzieh Meshkini]]. It tells three stories, each depicting a different stage in the lives of Iranian women. It [[première]]d at the 2000 [[Venice Film Festival]] and won several festival awards during 2000. Critical response was positive with some calling it "[[Federico Fellini|Felliniesque]]". ==Plot== The film tells three different stories about women struggling for identity in Iran.{{Citation | last = Harrison | first = Eric | title = The Day I Became a Woman | newspaper = [[Houston Chronicle]] | date = 2004-05-19 | url =http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ent/movies/906030.html | accessdate = 2008-03-08 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080319122412/http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ent/movies/906030.html |archivedate = 2008-03-19}} Hava is a young girl who, on her ninth birthday, is told by her mother and grandmother that she has become a woman with particular responsibilities. She may no longer play with her best friend, a boy, and must wear a [[chador]] when outside the home. Hava is given the choice when to start taking on those responsibilities—noon that day. A stick pushed into the ground will mark time as the shadow at noon will align with the stick.{{cite web | title = About the Film | publisher = Official site | url = http://www.thedayibecameawoman.com/ | accessdate =2008-03-08 }} Ahoo is a married woman who is taking part in a [[cycling]] race. Ahead of the rest, Ahoo is pursued by her husband on horseback. He tries to persuade her to stop cycling and come home, and then threatens her with [[divorce]]. When Ahoo defiantly continues cycling, her husband brings a [[mullah]] who divorces them. Later, tribal superiors and male family members come to stop Ahoo as she tries to escape the social constraints of being a woman. Hoora is an elderly widow who has recently inherited a great deal of money. She decides to buy all of the material possessions she has ever wanted, but could not have while she was married. She ties strings to her fingers to remind her what to buy, and hires several young boys to help her. They take her and her new belongings to the beach. As she floats out to a waiting ship, seemingly free from the bonds of womanhood, she is watched by two of the young women from the bicycle race, and Hava, now wearing her chador. ==Cast== * [[Fatemeh Cherag Akhar]] as Hava * [[Hassan Nebhan]] as Hassan * [[Shahr Banou Sisizadeh]] as Mother * [[Ameneh Passand]] as Grandmother * [[Shabnam Tolouei]] as Ahoo * [[Sirous Kahvarinegad]] as Husband * [[Mahram Zeinal Zadeh]] as Osmann * [[Norieh Mahigiran]] as Rival Cyclist * [[Azizeh Sedighi]] as Hoora * [[Badr Iravani]] as Young Boy ==Production== The film was co-written by director Marzieh Meshkini, from a script by her husband [[Mohsen Makhmalbaf]].{{Citation | last = Gleiberman | first = Owen | author-link = Owen Gleiberman | title = Women In Black | newspaper = [[Entertainment Weekly]] | date = 2001-04-20 | url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,280932,00.html | accessdate=2008-03-08}} It was shot on [[Kish Island]] in the [[Hormozgān Province]] in southern Iran.{{Citation | last = Young | first = Deborah | title = The Day I Became a Woman | newspaper = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date = 2000-09-18 | url = http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117788113.html?categoryid=31&cs=1&query=Day+i+became+a+woman | accessdate=2008-03-08}} Makhmalbaf was on the island at the same time, shooting ''[[Testing Democracy]]''.{{Citation | last = Rosenbaum | first = Jonathan | authorlink = Jonathan Rosenbaum | title = Essential Cinema: On the Necessity of Film Canons | publisher = [[JHU Press]] | year = 2004 | pages = 281 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=l0mo02cmZaQC | isbn = 0-8018-7840-3}} Some commentators have suggested that Makhmalbaf was the real director of ''The Day I Became a Woman'' (as well as the films of his daughters). Critic [[Jonathan Rosenbaum]] has argued against these claims. Meshkini has said that as a female filmmaker, she found making a film in Iran particularly difficult, having to prove her abilities to the cast and crew before being accepted by them.{{Citation | title = ArtsEtc: Answer The Questions - Marziyeh Meshkini: "I had to try" | newspaper = [[The Independent]] | date = 2002-01-20 | url =http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20020120/ai_n9669271 | accessdate =2008-03-09 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080320035128/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20020120/ai_n9669271 |archivedate = 2008-03-20}} ==Distribution and reception== ''The Day I Became a Woman'' [[première]]d at the 2000 [[Venice Film Festival]]. It went on to play at several festivals including the [[Toronto International Film Festival]], the [[London Film Festival]] and the New York [[New Directors/New Films Festival]]. It was given a limited release in American theatres on April 6, 2001. On its release in Iran, it was temporarily banned. The film won awards at the Venice Film Festival, the [[Toronto International Film Festival]], the [[Thessaloniki Film Festival]], the [[Pusan International Film Festival]], the [[Oslo Films from the South Festival]] and the [[Chicago International Film Festival]]. Critical response to the film was generally positive. Film review site [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gave it a score of 87% based on 55 reviews.{{cite web | title = The Day I Became A Woman (2001) | publisher = [[Rotten Tomatoes]] | url = http://uk.rottentomatoes.com/m/day_i_became_a_woman/ | accessdate =2008-03-08 }} [[Metacritic]] gave it a score of 84% based on 24 reviews.{{cite web | title = Day I Became a Woman, The | publisher = [[Metacritic]] | url = http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/dayibecameawoman | accessdate =2008-03-08 }} Writing for the ''[[New York Times]]'', [[Stephen Holden]] called it a "stunner of a film" and "an astonishing directorial debut".{{Citation | last = Holden | first = Stephen | author-link = Stephen Holden | title = The Day I Became A Woman — Outrun Fate? Not for Iranian Women | newspaper = [[New York Times]] | date = 2001-03-24 | url = https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9A07E3D7153CF937A15750C0A9679C8B63 | accessdate=2008-03-08}} He said that leaving characters' backgrounds and motives unexplored makes the film enigmatic. [[Roger Ebert]] said that the three stories lack "the psychological clutter of Western movies", describing this fact as a strength.{{Citation | last = Ebert | first = Roger | author-link = Roger Ebert | title = The Day I Became A Woman | newspaper = [[Chicago Sun-Times]] | date = 2001-04-06 | url = http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20010406/REVIEWS/104060303/1023 | accessdate=2008-03-08}} In the ''[[Boston Phoenix]]'', Chris Fujiwara said that the film was "largely successful, describing the second segment as the highlight, and calling the final story disappointing.{{Citation | last = Fujiwara | first = Chris | title = Female trouble — Marziyeh Meshkini’s auspicious debut | newspaper = [[Boston Phoenix]] | date = April 2001 | url = http://www.bostonphoenix.com/boston/movies/documents/01189086.htm | accessdate=2008-03-08}} In ''[[The New Yorker]]'', [[Michael Sragow]] called the film "fierce, inspired filmmaking".{{Citation | last = Sragow | first = Michael | author-link = Michael Sragow | title = The Day I Became a Woman | newspaper = [[The New Yorker]] | date = 2005-03-21 | url = http://www.newyorker.com/arts/reviews/film/the_day_i_became_a_woman_meshkini | accessdate=2008-03-08}} Several critics described it as "[[Federico Fellini|Felliniesque]]". ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.thedayibecameawoman.com/}} * {{IMDb title|0260332}} * {{Amg movie|220942|The Day I Became a Woman}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Day I Became a Woman}} [[Category:2000 films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:Directorial debut films]] [[Category:Feminist films]] [[Category:Iranian films]] [[Category:Persian-language films]]

'''The Poetry Forum, Inc.''',<ref name="ILInc">Secretary of State of Illinois, The Poetry Forum, Inc. Articles of Incorporation, 1976</ref> began in 1973<ref name="ILInc" /> to arrange poetry workshops in the [[Deerfield, Illinois]], area.<ref name="Rhino76">''RHINO Poetry, Vol. 1, No. 1, 1976, p. 40''</ref> In 1976, Suzanne Brabant and others founded the journal, ''[[RHINO Poetry]]'', as an outlet for its workshop members' poems.<ref name="RHINO">[http://rhinopoetry.org/about-2/history/ RHINO Poetry Website History]</ref> The Poetry Forum moved to the [[Evanston, Illinois]] area around 1999, where The Poetry Forum's workshops are still held monthly. The Forum extended its workshops to central Illinois from 2002-2007. The [[Illinois Arts Council]] awarded The Poetry Forum grants for operating costs in 2007,<ref name="IlArts07">[http://www.arts.illinois.gov/files/content/FY07.pdf ''Illinois Arts Council Annual Report Fiscal Year 2007'', p. 25 & 95]</ref> 2008,<ref name="IlArts08">[http://www.arts.illinois.gov/files/content/FY08annualreport.pdf ''Illinois Arts Council Annual Report Fiscal Year 2008'' pp. 35 & 95]</ref> and 2009.<ref name="IlArts09">[http://www.arts.illinois.gov/files/content/FY09_Grantee_List_by_District.pdf ''Illinois Arts Council Grants in FY 09 by State House District'', p. 16]</ref> The Poetry Forum was founded by Suzanne Brabant,<ref name="Poets74">''A Directory of American Poets, 1974''; Poets & Writers, Inc.; New York; 1974</ref> [[Lowell B. Komie]],<ref name="Komie">[http://www.swordfishchicago.com/ Swordfish Chicago Publishers]</ref> and Elizabeth Peterson.<ref name="Rhino76" /> In 2005, Helen Degen Cohen (Halina Degenfisz),<ref name="Blood">''Blood to Remember: American Poets on the Holocaust'' by Charles Adés Fishman; Time Being Books; St. Louis, Mo.; 2007; p. 582</ref> took over the Forum's mission of creating monthly workshops and readings for Evanston's poets.
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://rhinopoetry.org/ RHINO Poetry ] * [http://chicagopoetry.com/ ChicagoPoetry.com]
