{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Use British English|date=July 2017}} [[File:B300 Union Street - geograph.org.uk - 967279.jpg|thumb|right|Union Street.]] [[File:St Saviour's House, Union Street - geograph.org.uk - 920369.jpg|thumb|St Saviour's House]]
'''Union Street''' is a major street in the [[London Borough of Southwark]]. It runs between [[Blackfriars Road]] to the west and [[Borough High Street]] to the east.<ref>[http://www.london-se1.co.uk/street/union-street Union Street], London SE1 community website.</ref><ref>[http://www.londontown.com/LondonStreets/union_street_9be.html London guide to Union Street, SE1], LondonTown.com.</ref> [[Southwark Bridge Road]] crosses in the middle.
== History == The eastern part of the street was laid out under a 1774 Act passed for making a new workhouse and for "making a carriage way from the … High Street, through the Greyhound Inn, into Queen Street, and for improving the passage from thence into Gravel Lane, leading towards the Black Friars Bridge Road, in the parish of Christ Church."<ref>Sir Howard Roberts and Walter H. Godfrey (editors), [http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=65324 Union Street], ''Survey of London: volume 22: Bankside (the parishes of St. Saviour and Christchurch Southwark)'', Chapter 12, pages 84–86, 1950.</ref>
In 1782 the Union Hall was opened as the Surrey Magistrates Court in the borough, the JPs having previously sat at the Town Hall in the High Street. The façade of the Hall was retained on the new structure on the site in 2005.
In 1813, Queen Street and Duke Street were renamed Union Street. In 1908 Charlotte Street, at the western end of Union Street, was also renamed to be part of the street yet it clearly has a dislocated junction with it, exacerbated by it starting under the railway viaduct.
A fire at an oil and paint shop in Union Street in April 1885 resulted in the death of [[Alice Ayres]], whose bravery in saving her three nieces captured the public imagination.<ref>{{cite web|title=Alice Ayres - A Secular Saint|url=http://www.stmgrts.org.uk/archives/2013/03/alice_ayres_a_secular_saint.html|publisher=St Margarets Community Website|accessdate=15 February 2015}}</ref>
Red Cross Burial Ground was a burial ground at the northeast corner of Union Street and Red Cross Way.
The street was called Union Street because it marks the boundary between the two local parishes in the area.
==Amenities== The [[Union Theatre (London)|Union Theatre]] is a leading fringe venue on the north side of the street. On the south side is [[Jerwood Space]], an arts venue, located in the former Orange Street School.<ref>[http://www.jerwoodspace.co.uk/ Jerwood Space].</ref> Other art galleries include the [[RKB Gallery]], dedicated to artworks on paper,<ref>[http://www.rkburt.com/gallery/ RKB Gallery], R. K. Burt UK.</ref><ref>[http://www.london-se1.co.uk/places/rkb-gallery RKB Gallery], London SE1 community website.</ref> and the [[Union Gallery]], a contemporary art gallery under the railway arches on the north side, that moved to Teesdale Road in February 2009.<ref>[http://www.london-se1.co.uk/places/union-gallery Union Gallery], London SE1 community website</ref>
Public houses on the street include the Charles Dickens and the Lord Nelson, named after two famous Englishmen. Dickens lodged in [[Lant Street]] not far away as a child.
==Transport== [[Southwark tube station|Southwark Underground station]] is at the western end. [[Southwark Street]] runs in parallel to the north. The road forms part of the B300, linking with [[The Cut (London)|The Cut]] to the west. To the east is Newcomen Street.
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == {{commons category inline|Union Street, London}} {{coord|51|30|13|N|0|5|53|W|display=title}}
[[Category:Streets in the London Borough of Southwark]] [[Category:Art gallery districts]]

{{Infobox person | name = Yolanda García Serrano | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1958}} | birth_place = [[Madrid]], Spain | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | other_names = | occupation = Director, writer | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = | spouse = | children = Cora Tiedra | awards = {{Plainlist| * [[Goya Award for Best Original Screenplay]] (1994) * {{ill|Lope de Vega Award|es|Premio Lope de Vega}} (2013) }} | alma_mater = }} '''Yolanda García Serrano''' (born 1958) is a Spanish film director and writer, the winner of the 1994 [[Goya Award for Best Original Screenplay]] for the film ''[[All Men Are the Same]]''.<ref name=Goya>{{Cite news |url=https://elpais.com/diario/1997/04/09/madrid/860585079_850215.html |title='En Madrid surgen historias por todas partes' |trans-title='In Madrid, Stories Emerge Everywhere' |first=Dolores |last=Conquero |work=[[El País]] |location=Madrid |language=Spanish |date=9 April 1997 |access-date=26 August 2018}}</ref>
==Biography== García studied Public Relations and worked for a few years as a secretary while starting her studies in Dramatic Arts.<ref name=Sofia>{{Cite journal |url=http://arbor.revistas.csic.es/index.php/arbor/article/view/794/801 |title=Sofia entre mujeres |trans-title=Sofia Between Women |work=Arbor |volume=185 |number=A1 |language=Spanish |date=2009 |access-date=26 August 2018}}</ref> She immediately began to participate in a theater group and to write small works, first for the children's audience and then for adults. She studied dramatic writing with {{ill|Fermín Cabal|es}}, [[José Luis Alonso de Santos]], and {{ill|Jesús Campos García|es|lt=Jesús Campos}},<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZpwlYIqjE78C&lpg=PA196&pg=PA196 |title=Miradas a la escena de fin de siglo: Escritos dispersos II |trans-title=Looking at the Scene at the End of the Century: Dispersed Writings II |chapter=La dramaturgia española actual (1975–2000) |trans-chapter=Current Spanish Dramaturgy (1975–2000) |first=Guillermo |last=Heras |publisher=[[University of Valencia]] |isbn=9788437054292 |page=196 |language=Spanish |year=2002 |access-date=27 August 2018 |via=Google Books}}</ref> and later studied audiovisual and cinematographic narrative, as well as film direction. She then began writing for film, television, and theater.
In 1986, and within a dramaturgy workshop of the National Center of New Trends, her play ''La llamada es del todo inadecuada'' was selected along with two others to be performed at the [[Círculo de Bellas Artes]] in Madrid. It was a completely new project in Spanish drama with a work framed in the theater of the absurd.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://elpais.com/diario/1986/01/04/cultura/505177205_850215.html |title=El misterio de la dramaturgia |trans-title=The Mystery of Dramaturgy |first=Eduardo |last=Haro Tecglen |work=[[El País]] |language=Spanish |date=4 January 1986 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> She began working in cinematic screenwriting with [[Joaquín Oristrell]], {{ill|Lola Salvador Maldonado|es|lt=Lola Salvador}}, and {{ill|Manolo Matji|es}}, but despite having gone through specialized schools with American and Hispanic writers, García confesses that she learned the trade by writing, reading, going a lot to the movies, "and throwing many scripts to the basket." Later she also went on to teach at the [[Community of Madrid]]'s Cinematography and Audiovisual School.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://elpais.com/diario/1998/03/24/sociedad/890694033_850215.html |title=García Serrano: 'Aprendí tirando guiones al cesto' |trans-title=García Serrano: 'I Learned Throwing Scripts to the Basket' |first=Susana |last=Pérez de Pablos |work=[[El País]] |location=Madrid |language=Spanish |date=24 March 1998 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref>
In 1988, she began her career as a professional screenwriter with works for film, television programs, and series. From the beginning she formed a team working in collaboration with [[Manuel Gómez Pereira]], {{ill|Juan Luis Iborra|es}}, and Joaquín Oristrell. In 1994, and in collaboration with them, she won the [[Goya Award for Best Original Screenplay]] for ''[[All Men Are the Same]]''.<ref name=Goya/> Among the series she has written for are ''[[Farmacia de guardia]]'' (1991–1995), ''{{ill|Abuela de verano|es}}'' (2005), ''Clara Campoamor'', and ''{{ill|Fugitiva|es}}'' (2018).<ref name=Fugitiva>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rtve.es/television/20170720/paz-vega-protagonizara-fugitiva-nueva-serie-rtve-empezara-rodarse-noviembre/1584521.shtml |title=Paz Vega protagonizará 'Fugitiva', la nueva serie de RTVE que empezará a rodarse en noviembre |trans-title=Paz Vega Will Star in 'Fugitiva', the New RTVE Series That Will Begin Shooting in November |publisher=[[RTVE]] |language=Spanish |date=20 July 2017 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> In movies, she wrote ''[[Why Do They Call It Love When They Mean Sex?]]'' (1993), ''[[Love Can Seriously Damage Your Health]]'' (1997), ''[[Queens (film)|Queens]]'' (2005), and ''[[Mediterranean Food]]'' (2008).
In 1997, García directed and wrote the screenplay for ''[[Amor de hombre]]'' with Juan Luis Iborra, which she later turned into a novel. The film won the 1st Award for the best film of the L.A. Gay & Lesbian Film Festival. After ten years removed from the scene, she returned in 1998 with a comedy about marriage, written specifically for three actresses – [[Carmen Balagué]], {{ill|Elisa Matilla|es}}, and Rosario Santesmases – entitled ''Qué asco de amor''. She received the Hogar Sur de Teatro de Comedias Award, organized by the Pedro Muñoz Seca Foundation.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://elpais.com/diario/1998/09/08/paisvasco/905283621_850215.html |title=Yolanda García Serrano vuelve al teatro con una comedia sobre el matrimonio |trans-title=Yolanda García Serrano Returns to Theater with a Comedy About Matrimony |first=Marta |last=Nieto |work=[[El País]] |location=Bilbao |language=Spanish |date=8 September 1998 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> With ''Dónde pongo la cabeza'', released in 2006, she won the Chivas Telón Award.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.abc.es/hemeroteca/historico-09-09-2006/abc/Toledo/yolanda-garcia-serrano-pone-humor-al-maltrato-en-donde-pongo-la-cabeza_1423221607775.html |title=Yolanda García Serrano pone humor al maltrato en '¿Dónde pongo la cabeza?' |trans-title=Yolanda García Serrano Puts Humor into Abuse in '¿Dónde pongo la cabeza?' |work=[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]] |location=Madrid |language=Spanish |date=9 September 2006 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref>
In 2000, again together with Juan Luis Iborra, she directed and wrote ''[[Km. 0]]'', winner for the best film of the [[Torino Film Festival]]. Two years later, she premiered her first solo film, the family comedy ''Hasta aquí hemos llegado'' (2002). Her play ''Ser o no ser Cervantes'', premiered in New York in 2010, won three [[Hispanic Organization of Latin Actors]] (HOLA) Awards. In 2011 she was the first Spanish woman to premiere and direct her own play in New York: ''Good sex. Good day. Lo que ellos ignoran de ellas''.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rtve.es/alacarta/audios/entrevista-en-r5/entrevista-radio-5-yolanda-garcia-serrano-quiero-tener-poder-decision-sobre-misma/1022123/ |title=Entrevista en Radio 5 – Yolanda García Serrano: 'Quiero tener poder de decisión sobre mí misma' |trans-title=Interview on Radio 5 – Yolanda García Serrano: 'I Want to Have Decision-Making Power Over Myself' |publisher=[[RTVE]] |language=Spanish |date=17 February 2011 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> Along with {{ill|Juan Carlos Rubio|es}}, she received the 2013 {{ill|Lope de Vega Award|es|Premio Lope de Vega}} for a work not yet released: ''Shakespeare nunca estuvo aquí''.<ref name=Rubio>{{Cite news |url=http://www.elmundo.es/cultura/2014/10/13/543bcb26268e3e38548b4596.html |title=Yolanda García-Serrano y Juan Carlos Rubio, premio Lope de Vega |trans-title=Yolanda García-Serrano and Juan Carlos Rubio, Lope de Vega Award |work=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]] |agency=EFE |location=Madrid |language=Spanish |date=13 October 2014 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> In 2013, she was commissioned as artistic director of the [[Premios Max]] gala, presented that year by actor {{ill|Álex O'Dogherty|es}}.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.hoyesarte.com/artes-escenicas/teatro/alex-o%C2%B4dogherty-presentara-la-gala-de-los-premios-max_114676/ |title=Alex O'Dogherty presenta la gala de los Premios Max |work=Hoyes Arte |language=Spanish |date=13 May 2013 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref>
García has always worked in the field of comedy, which was for her a way to face and overcome the most dramatic reality, until in 2016 she premiered her first drama, ''¡Corre!'', in collaboration with Joaquín Oristrell.<ref name=Corre>{{Cite news |url=https://www.lavanguardia.com/local/madrid/20160310/40343096880/corre-el-primer-drama-de-yolanda-garcia-serrano-en-la-sala-mirador.html |title='¡Corre!', el primer drama de Yolanda García Serrano, en la Sala Mirador |trans-title='¡Corre!', the First Drama by García Serrano, at the Sala Mirador |work=[[La Vanguardia]] |language=Spanish |date=10 March 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180716201702/https://www.lavanguardia.com/local/madrid/20160310/40343096880/corre-el-primer-drama-de-yolanda-garcia-serrano-en-la-sala-mirador.html |archive-date=16 July 2018 |dead-url=yes |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> This was based on her own experience, as she explained in an interview conducted by {{ill|Pepa Fernández|es}} on the Radio Nacional de España program ''{{ill|No es un día cualquiera|es}}'' in October 2017.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rtve.es/alacarta/audios/no-es-un-dia-cualquiera/entrevista-yolanda-garcia-serrano-neudc-151017-2017-10-15t11-52-165701339/4257156/ |title=No es un día cualquiera – Yolanda García Serrano: Necesito la comedia para estar viva' |trans-title=No es un día cualquiera – Yolanda García Serrano: 'I Need Comedy to Be Alive' |publisher=[[RTVE]] |language=Spanish |date=15 October 2017 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref>
In 2017 she was a finalist in the 1st [[Teatro Español (Madrid)|Teatro Español]] Playwriting Tournament with her work ''Parapeto'', eventually losing to {{ill|Ignacio del Moral|es}}.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://elpais.com/cultura/2017/06/14/actualidad/1497440495_736088.html |title=Último asalto en el combate de palabras |trans-title=Last Assault in the Battle of Words |first=Rocío |last=García |work=[[El País]] |language=Spanish |date=14 June 2017 |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> She has also made incursions into micro-theater with the play ''La novia de nuestro hijo no es nuestra hija''.<ref>{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.revistacactus.com/micro-teatro-por-primera-vez/ |title=Micro-teatro: Por primera vez |trans-title=Micro-Theater: For the First Time |first=Koldo |last=Gutiérrez |work=Cactus |language=Spanish |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref>
Some of García's cinematic works feature leading or supporting performances by her daughter Cora Tiedra, who has also appeared on some television series.<ref>{{Cite magazine |url=http://www.fotogramas.es/Peliculas/!Hasta-aqui-hemos-llegado/!Hasta-aqui-hemos-llegado |title=¡Hasta aquí hemos llegado! |trans-title=So Far We Have Come! |work=Fotogramas |date=25 June 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180716194618/http://www.fotogramas.es/Peliculas/!Hasta-aqui-hemos-llegado/!Hasta-aqui-hemos-llegado |archive-date=16 July 2018 |dead-url=yes |access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref>
==Works== * 1991 – ''Salsa rosa'' * 1994 – ''Todos los hombres sois iguales'' * 1997 – ''Amor de hombre'' * 2000 – ''Km. 0'' * 2002 – ''Hasta aquí hemos llegado''
===Television=== * 1991–1995 – ''[[Farmacia de Guardia]]'' * 2005 – ''Abuela de verano'' * 2018 – ''Fugitiva''<ref name=Fugitiva/>
===Books=== * 1993 – ''Línea caliente'' * 1997 – ''Amor de hombre,'' novel based on the author's film script in collaboration with Juan Luis Iborra * 2000 – ''Siempre me enamoro del hombre equivocado'' * 2001 – ''De qué va eso del amor'', in co-authorship with Verónica Fernández Rodríguez * 2004 – ''Mujer casada busca gente que la lleve al cine'' * 2007 – ''Descalza por la vida'', in co-authorship with Verónica Fernández Rodríguez
===Theater=== * 1986 – ''La llamada es del todo inadecuada'' * 1998 – ''Qué asco de amor'' * 2007 – ''Dónde pongo la cabeza'' * 2013 – ''Shakespeare nunca estuvo aquí'', in co-authorship with Juan Carlos Rubio, Lope de Vega Award winner<ref name=Rubio/> * 2016 – ''¡Corre!'', in collaboration with Joaquín Oristrell<ref name=Corre/>
